column3:
Level 1:
Basic Basic awareness and foundational knowledge. Requires close supervision and detailed guidance.
column4:
Level 2:
Intermediate Working knowledge and consistent application. Needs periodic supervision and support for complex tasks.
column5:
Level 3:
Advanced Comprehensive understanding and independent application. Can handle most complex situations and guide others.
column6:
Level 4:
Expert Complete mastery, innovation, and leadership. Sets standards, develops new approaches, and mentors others.

column1: Functional Skills: technical or job-related skills that are necessary to perform tasks within a particular role
column3: Basic awareness and foundational knowledge. Requires close supervision and detailed guidance. Can identify basic AWS services relevant to the scenario but requires significant guidance to understand how they contribute to high availability, scalability, backups, or disaster recovery. May struggle to articulate basic concepts or provide specific AWS service examples. Has limited awareness of associated costs, complexity, or potential single points of failure.
column4: Working knowledge and consistent application. Needs periodic supervision and support for complex tasks. Can describe common AWS services for high availability (e.g., Load Balancers, Auto Scaling Groups), scalability, backups (e.g., EBS snapshots), and disaster recovery (e.g., cross-region replication). Can explain basic architectural patterns such as multi-AZ deployments and fundamental auto-scaling principles. Can articulate basic data replication or redundancy strategies (e.g., RDS, DynamoDB, or S3). May need some support when discussing trade-offs between cost and resiliency, or when addressing more complex scenarios like multi-region deployments or advanced auto-scaling.
column5: Comprehensive understanding and independent application. Can handle most complex situations and guide others. Demonstrates a comprehensive understanding of architecting for high availability, scalability, robust backups, and disaster recovery on AWS. Can articulate various strategies, including multi-AZ and multi-region deployments, advanced auto-scaling (e.g., Karpenter on EKS), and cross-region replication for disaster recovery. Can discuss trade-offs in detail, including cost, complexity, and defining and testing RPO (Recovery Point Objective) and RTO (Recovery Time Objective). Provides specific examples of AWS services (e.g., ALB, NLB, RDS, DynamoDB, S3) and their effective application within the HR management platform scenario. Can also discuss cost optimization strategies such as instance rightsizing, advanced cost monitoring, and the use of serverless architectures where appropriate, leveraging tools like AWS Cost Explorer or CloudWatch metrics.
column6: Complete mastery, innovation, and leadership. Sets standards, develops new approaches, and mentors others. Exhibits complete mastery in designing and implementing highly available, scalable, resilient, and cost-optimized AWS architectures. Can innovate and develop new approaches to solve complex architectural challenges, setting standards for the organization. Provides a comprehensive overview of multi-AZ/multi-region deployments, advanced auto-scaling groups, various data replication/redundancy strategies, and robust disaster recovery plans with clearly defined RPO/RTO. Discusses trade-offs in depth, including cost considerations, performance vs. cost, and security aspects (e.g., CloudFront or WAF for edge delivery and security). Can lead discussions on advanced cost optimization strategies, including the use of AWS Cost Explorer, CloudWatch metrics, and third-party cost analysis tools, and effectively mentor others in these areas. May reference tools like Terraform or Crossplane to deploy architecture predictably and repetitively across environments, and discuss ephemeral vs. persistent storage.

column3: Basic awareness and foundational knowledge. Requires close supervision and detailed guidance. Can identify basic Kubernetes concepts (e.g., Pods, Deployments) but requires significant guidance to understand how they contribute to release automation or reliability. May struggle to articulate basic deployment strategies or the importance of automated testing.
column4: Working knowledge and consistent application. Needs periodic supervision and support for complex tasks. Can describe common Kubernetes deployment strategies (e.g., rolling updates) and the role of CI/CD in release automation. Understands the importance of automated testing and basic monitoring. May need some support when discussing advanced deployment strategies (blue/green, canary) or comprehensive rollback plans.
column5: Comprehensive understanding and independent application. Can handle most complex situations and guide others. Demonstrates a comprehensive understanding of designing a release process for Kubernetes that minimizes downtime and ensures reliability. Can articulate various deployment strategies (e.g., blue/green, canary releases, rolling updates), the role of immutable infrastructure, and GitOps principles (e.g., ArgoCD, FluxCD). Can discuss automated testing, monitoring, and robust rollback strategies.
column6: Complete mastery, innovation, and leadership. Sets standards, develops new approaches, and mentors others. Exhibits complete mastery in designing and implementing highly reliable and automated release processes for Kubernetes. Can innovate and develop new approaches to solve complex release challenges. Provides a comprehensive explanation of a robust CI/CD pipeline integrated with Kubernetes, covering advanced deployment strategies (blue/green, canary), automated testing, observability, and a well-defined rollback plan. Discusses the use of service meshes (Istio, Linkerd) for traffic management and mentors others in best practices.

column3: Basic awareness and foundational knowledge. Requires close supervision and detailed guidance. Can identify basic Terraform concepts (e.g., resources, providers) but requires significant guidance to understand how they contribute to reusability, maintainability, or disaster recovery. May struggle to articulate basic module usage or state management.
column4: Working knowledge and consistent application. Needs periodic supervision and support for complex tasks. Can describe common Terraform practices for organizing code (e.g., basic module usage), managing state (e.g., local state, basic remote state), and understands the importance of IaC for disaster recovery. May need some support when discussing advanced module versioning or multi-region DR strategies.
column5: Comprehensive understanding and independent application. Can handle most complex situations and guide others. Demonstrates a comprehensive understanding of organizing Terraform code for reusability and maintainability (e.g., well-structured modules, workspaces). Can articulate strategies for managing remote state (e.g., S3 backend) and versioning modules. Can also explain how to leverage IaC for robust multi-region disaster recovery, including automated provisioning and DR drills.
column6: Complete mastery, innovation, and leadership. Sets standards, develops new approaches, and mentors others. Exhibits complete mastery in designing and implementing highly reusable, maintainable, and secure Terraform projects. Can innovate and develop new approaches for complex IaC challenges, including advanced state management, CI/CD integration, and multi-region DR strategies (e.g., blue/green, canary deployments for DR). Provides detailed explanations of secrets management, security best practices, and compliance in Terraform. May mention tools like Terragrunt or Atlantis for advanced workflows.

column3: Basic awareness and foundational knowledge. Requires close supervision and detailed guidance. Can identify basic operational concepts (e.g., monitoring, backups) but requires significant guidance to understand how they contribute to uptime, incident response, or automation. May struggle to articulate basic monitoring tools or incident management steps.
column4: Working knowledge and consistent application. Needs periodic supervision and support for complex tasks. Can describe common monitoring tools (e.g., CloudWatch, basic Grafana), basic incident management steps, and the importance of automation. Understands basic concepts of dashboards, alerts, and on-call rotations. May need some support when discussing advanced alerting strategies or comprehensive incident response plans.
column5: Comprehensive understanding and independent application. Can handle most complex situations and guide others. Demonstrates a comprehensive understanding of designing and implementing monitoring and alerting strategies (e.g., Prometheus, Grafana, Datadog, ELK stack). Can articulate robust incident management processes, including communication plans, root cause analysis, and blameless post-mortems. Can identify and propose automation for repetitive tasks, discussing various scripting languages and tools.
column6: Complete mastery, innovation, and leadership. Sets standards, develops new approaches, and mentors others. Exhibits complete mastery in designing and implementing highly reliable and automated operational processes. Can innovate and develop new approaches for complex monitoring, incident management, and automation challenges. Provides a detailed strategy for comprehensive monitoring (infrastructure, application, business-level), advanced alerting (PagerDuty, Opsgenie), and a blameless post-mortem culture. Emphasizes observability, shift-left monitoring, and secure, testable, and maintainable automation.

column1: Team Work: interpersonal or soft skills to work effectively with others in a collaborative environment
column3: Struggles to communicate technical ideas clearly; documentation is incomplete or confusing. Has difficulty collaborating with others, leading to misunderstandings or rework.
column4: Communicates basic ideas but inconsistently; documentation lacks clarity or depth. Collaboration is present but often reactive; alignment across teams is limited.
column5: Explains technical choices clearly within the team, maintains proper documentation, and collaborates effectively with peers to deliver aligned solutions.
column6: Communicates complex technical concepts clearly across teams, facilitates smooth cross-functional collaboration, and mentors others on documentation and effective teamwork.

column1: Business Impact: skills that influence on the overall success and strategic direction of the organization
column3: Avoids responsibility, lacks follow-through, frequently misses deadlines, and needs constant supervision.
column4: Takes responsibility but requires frequent reminders, struggles to work autonomously, and does not proactively solve issues.
column5: Reliable, ensures follow-through on tasks, takes initiative when needed, and delivers assigned work on time.
column6: Takes full ownership, proactively drives solutions, aligns with stakeholders, and removes blockers for the team.

column2: TECHNICAL CRITICAL THINKING (Code Quality & System Design)
column3: Struggles to analyze and resolve problems, frequently introduces new bugs, requires constant guidance for debugging and troubleshooting.
column4: Solves basic problems but lacks independent thinking, often applies quick fixes without addressing root causes.
column5: Strong analytical thinker, resolves most issues independently, applies structured problem-solving approaches.
column6: Proactively identifies potential issues, optimizes solutions, and improves system performance with minimal oversight.

column2: TECHNICAL CRITICAL THINKING (Code Quality & System Design)
column3: Weak technical skills, struggles with engineering fundamentals, writes inefficient or error-prone code, and frequently needs rework.
column4: Has a basic understanding of technical concepts but needs guidance for complex tasks, occasionally writes suboptimal or unscalable code.
column5: Strong technical skills, writes clean, maintainable, and efficient code, follows best practices, and designs robust solutions.
column6: Highly skilled in writing optimized, scalable, and secure code. Refactors and improves existing codebases, mentors others on best practices, and actively participates in system design discussions.

column3: Slow execution, struggles to complete tasks on time, resists adopting new technologies, and frequently fails to adjust to changing project needs. Often overwhelmed under pressure.
column4: Manages workload but struggles with adaptability, requires significant guidance to pick up new tools or frameworks, and has difficulty handling unexpected challenges.
column5: Works efficiently, balances speed and quality, adapts well to new technologies, and can adjust workflows when priorities shift. Handles pressure in a steady manner.
column6: Quickly learns and integrates new tools and frameworks, efficiently refactors code to improve performance, and remains highly productive even in high-pressure situations.
